title: 105_hr3568
content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if similar restrictions are not placed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 allow group health plans to include mental health benefits without treatment limitations or financial requirements if similar restrictions are not placed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. This section does not prohibit negotiating separate reimbursement rates or managing benefits through mechanisms like pre-admission screening. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require group health plans to provide mental health benefits without treatment limits based solely on medical necessity. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require group health plans to provide mental health benefits without treatment limits based solely on medical necessity. The amendments also eliminate cost exemptions, sunset provisions, and expand coverage to include treatment limitations and financial requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits in group health plans, prohibiting treatment limitations or financial requirements on mental health coverage if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits in group health plans, prohibiting separate reimbursement rates and service delivery systems for different benefits, managing benefits through pre-admission screening, and prior authorization, and not requiring specific mental health benefits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in mental health benefit limits in group health plans. This includes defining treatment and financial limits, eliminating cost exemptions, and removing the sunset provision. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is further amended by eliminating the sunset provision and making clerical amendments. Additionally, a new section is added to Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act. "SEC. 2752. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO MENTAL HEALTH BENEFITS." The provisions of section 2705 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment. Employers with collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of this Act are exempt from certain plan amendments until the later of the termination of the agreements or July 1, 1999. Amendments solely to comply with new requirements are not considered terminations. Individual health insurance coverage amendment applies to coverage in the individual market on or after July 1, 1999. Coordination in implementation involves amending section 104(1) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, Public Health Service Act, and Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are referenced in the text. SEC. 3. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to ensure that benefits for substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment are treated the same as mental health benefits. Sec. 713 amends the Public Health Service Act to ensure parity in limits for substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits. This applies to group health plans and health insurance issuers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is also amended to include this parity for group health plans. Sec. 9813 ensures parity in limits for substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits, applying the same rules as for mental health benefits. This amendment also applies to individual health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 2753 ensures parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits. The provisions of section 2752 apply to benefits for substance abuse treatment in the same way as for mental health benefits. Effective dates for group health plans start on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) do not apply to plan years starting before the later of the termination of collective bargaining agreements or July 1, 1999. Plan amendments made to comply with new requirements will not be considered a termination of the collective bargaining agreement. Individual health insurance coverage amendment applies to coverage in the individual market on or after July 1, 1999, without terminating collective bargaining agreements.
